description:
Aspergillus costaricaensis CBS 115574 is a species of filamentous fungus belonging to the genus Aspergillus. It was first isolated from soil samples collected in Costa Rica, hence the specific epithet "costaricaensis."

Aspergillus costaricaensis is a member of the Aspergillus section Fumigati, which includes several important species of medical and industrial relevance. The fungus grows as a mold, forming a dense network of hyphae that can appear in various colors, such as green, brown, or black, depending on the stage of spore production.

Morphologically, A. costaricaensis produces conidiophores (specialized reproductive structures) that terminate in a globose vesicle, from which numerous phialides (specialized conidiogenous cells) radiate. These phialides produce chains of small, smooth-walled conidia (asexual spores) that contribute to the fungal colony's characteristic appearance.

Genetically, A. costaricaensis can be distinguished from other Aspergillus species within the Fumigati section based on the analysis of various molecular markers, such as the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of the ribosomal DNA and the Î²-tubulin gene sequence.

The ecological role and potential applications of A. costaricaensis are not yet fully understood, as it is a relatively newly described species. Further research is needed to explore its potential in biotechnological or medical contexts, as well as its interactions with other organisms in the environments where it is found.
